natural problem:
Three noncollinear points and a line $\ell$ are given in the plane. Suppose no two of the points lie on a line parallel to $\ell$ (or $\ell$ itself). There are exactly $n$ lines $m$ perpendicular to $\ell$ with the following property: the three circles with centers at the given points and tangent to line $m$ all concur at some point. Find all possible values of $n$.

Enter all possible values of $n,$ separated by commas.
natural solution: The condition for line $m$ is that each of the three points lies at an equal distance from the line as from some fixed point; in other words, the line is the directrix of a parabola containing the three points, and the fixed point is the focus.

[asy] unitsize (1 cm); real func (real x) {   return(x^2/4); } real a, b, c; pair A, B, C, F; a = -2; b = 1.5; c = 3; A = (a,func(a)); B = (b,func(b)); C = (c,func(c)); F = (0,1); draw(graph(func,-4,5),red);

draw(Circle(A,abs(A - F))); draw(Circle(B,abs(B - F))); draw(Circle(C,abs(C - F))); draw((-4,-1)--(6,-1)); draw(A--F,dashed); draw(B--F,dashed); draw(C--F,dashed); draw(A--(a,-1),dashed); draw(B--(b,-1),dashed);

draw(C--(c,-1),dashed); draw((-3,-2)--(-3,5.5)); label("$m$", (6,-1), E); label("$\ell$", (-3,5.5), N); dot(A); dot(B); dot(C); [/asy] Three noncollinear points in the coordinate plane determine a quadratic polynomial in $x$ unless two of the points have the same $x$-coordinate.

Therefore, given the direction of the directrix, three noncollinear points determine a parabola, unless two of the points lie on a line perpendicular to the directrix. This case is ruled out by the given condition, so the answer is $\boxed{1}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes l m :: "'a::euclidean_space \<Rightarrow> real" and A B C :: "'a::euclidean_space"
assumes h0 : "A ≠ B"
and h1 : "A ≠ C"
and h2 : "B ≠ C"
and h3 : "l ≠ m"
and h4 : "\<not> (collinear {A,B,C})"
and h5 : "\<nexists> l'. parallel l' l \<and> (A \<in> l' \<or> B \<in> l' \<or> C \<in> l')"
and h6 : "\<exists>! m. perpendicular m l \<and> (\<forall> X \<in> {A,B,C}. \<exists> r. circle X r m)"
shows  "card {m. perpendicular m l \<and> (\<forall> X \<in> {A,B,C}. \<exists> r. circle X r m)} = 1"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three noncollinear points and a line $\ell$ are given in the plane. Suppose no two of the points lie on a line parallel to $\ell$ (or $\ell$ itself). There are exactly $n$ lines $m$ perpendicular to $\ell$ with the following property: the three circles with centers at the given points and tangent to line $m$ all concur at some point. Find all possible values of $n$.

Enter all possible values of $n,$ separated by commas. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 The condition for line $m$ is that each of the three points lies at an equal distance from the line as from some fixed point; in other words, the line is the directrix of a parabola containing the three points, and the fixed point is the focus.
 [asy] unitsize (1 cm); real func (real x) {   return(x^2/4); } real a, b, c; pair A, B, C, F; a = -2; b = 1.5; c = 3; A = (a,func(a)); B = (b,func(b)); C = (c,func(c)); F = (0,1); draw(graph(func,-4,5),red);
 draw(Circle(A,abs(A - F))); draw(Circle(B,abs(B - F))); draw(Circle(C,abs(C - F))); draw((-4,-1)--(6,-1)); draw(A--F,dashed); draw(B--F,dashed); draw(C--F,dashed); draw(A--(a,-1),dashed); draw(B--(b,-1),dashed);
 draw(C--(c,-1),dashed); draw((-3,-2)--(-3,5.5)); label("$m$", (6,-1), E); label("$\ell$", (-3,5.5), N); dot(A); dot(B); dot(C); [/asy] Three noncollinear points in the coordinate plane determine a quadratic polynomial in $x$ unless two of the points have the same $x$-coordinate.
 Therefore, given the direction of the directrix, three noncollinear points determine a parabola, unless two of the points lie on a line perpendicular to the directrix. This case is ruled out by the given condition, so the answer is $\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes l m :: "'a::euclidean_space \<Rightarrow> real" and A B C :: "'a::euclidean_space"
assumes h0 : "A ≠ B"
and h1 : "A ≠ C"
and h2 : "B ≠ C"
and h3 : "l ≠ m"
and h4 : "\<not> (collinear {A,B,C})"
and h5 : "\<nexists> l'. parallel l' l \<and> (A \<in> l' \<or> B \<in> l' \<or> C \<in> l')"
and h6 : "\<exists>! m. perpendicular m l \<and> (\<forall> X \<in> {A,B,C}. \<exists> r. circle X r m)"
shows  "card {m. perpendicular m l \<and> (\<forall> X \<in> {A,B,C}. \<exists> r. circle X r m)} = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given three non-collinear points A, B, and C in the Euclidean space, and two distinct lines l and m. Assume that there exists no line parallel to l that passes through any of A, B, or C. Prove that there exists one and only one line m that is perpendicular to l and for each point among A, B, and C, there exists a circle with the center at the point and lies on the line m. The set of such lines m has exactly one element.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int and P Q R :: "real \<times> real" and l m :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<not> collinear P Q R"
and h1 : "\<forall> m. m \<noteq> l \<and> m \<parallel> l \<Longrightarrow> \<not> (P on m \<or> Q on m \<or> R on m)"
and h2 : "\<forall> m. m \<perp> l \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> p. p is_concurrent_with (circle P m) (circle Q m) (circle R m))"
and h3 : "card {m. m \<perp> l \<and> (\<exists> p. p is_concurrent_with (circle P m) (circle Q m) (circle R m))} = n"
shows  "n = 1"
a_1.formal solution:

Find all possible values of $n$.

Enter all possible values of $n,$ separated by commas. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof

 Therefore, given the direction of the directrix, three noncollinear points determine a parabola, unless two of the points lie on a line perpendicular to the directrix. This case is ruled out by the given condition, so the answer is $\boxed{1}$.

theorem
fixes n :: int and P Q R :: "real \<times> real" and l m :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<not> collinear P Q R"
and h1 : "\<forall> m. m \<noteq> l \<and> m \<parallel> l \<Longrightarrow> \<not> (P on m \<or> Q on m \<or> R on m)"
and h2 : "\<forall> m. m \<perp> l \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> p. p is_concurrent_with (circle P m) (circle Q m) (circle R m))"
and h3 : "card {m. m \<perp> l \<and> (\<exists> p. p is_concurrent_with (circle P m) (circle Q m) (circle R m))} = n"
shows  "n = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Assume we have three points P, Q, and R that are not collinear. Also, assume that any line m that is not line l and is parallel to line l does not pass through any of the points P, Q, or R. Further assume that for any line m that is perpendicular to line l, there exists a point p that is concurrent with the circles centered at points P, Q, and R with radii equal to the distance from these points to line m. If the number of such lines m is denoted by n, prove that n equals 1.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n m l :: real and A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<nexists> l. A l = B l \<or> A l = C l \<or> B l = C l"
and h1 : "\<nexists> l. parallel l m"
and h2 : "perpendicular l m"
and h3 : "\<exists> p. tangent p (circle A) \<and> tangent p (circle B) \<and> tangent p (circle C)"
and h4 : "\<forall> p. tangent p (circle A) \<and> tangent p (circle B) \<and> tangent p (circle C) \<longrightarrow> concurrent p"
shows  "n = 1"
a_2.formal solution:

There are exactly $n$ lines $m$ perpendicular to $\ell$ with the following property: the three circles with centers at the given points and tangent to line $m$ all concur at some point. Find all possible values of $n$.

Enter all possible values of $n,$ separated by commas. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 The condition for line $m$ is that each of the three points lies at an equal distance from the line as from some fixed point; in other words, the line is the directrix of a parabola containing the three points, and the fixed point is the focus.
 [asy] unitsize (1 cm); real func (real x) {   return(x^2/4); } real a, b, c; pair A, B, C, F; a = -2; b = 1.5; c = 3; A = (a,func(a)); B = (b,func(b)); C = (c,func(c)); F = (0,1); draw(graph(func,-4,5),red);

 draw(C--(c,-1),dashed); draw((-3,-2)--(-3,5.5)); label("$m$", (6,-1), E); label("$\ell$", (-3,5.5), N); dot(A); dot(B); dot(C); [/asy] Three noncollinear points in the coordinate plane determine a quadratic polynomial in $x$ unless two of the points have the same $x$-coordinate.
 Therefore, given the direction of the directrix, three noncollinear points determine a parabola, unless two of the points lie on a line perpendicular to the directrix. This case is ruled out by the given condition, so the answer is $\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n m l :: real and A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<nexists> l. A l = B l \<or> A l = C l \<or> B l = C l"
and h1 : "\<nexists> l. parallel l m"
and h2 : "perpendicular l m"
and h3 : "\<exists> p. tangent p (circle A) \<and> tangent p (circle B) \<and> tangent p (circle C)"
and h4 : "\<forall> p. tangent p (circle A) \<and> tangent p (circle B) \<and> tangent p (circle C) \<longrightarrow> concurrent p"
shows  "n = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Assume that there are three circles whose centers are represented by the functions A, B, and C. Suppose that there is no line that is parallel to a given line 'm' and there is a line 'l' that is perpendicular to line 'm'. Furthermore, consider that there is a point 'p' that touches all three circles (A, B, and C) at a single point each (i.e., it is tangent to all three circles). If all such points 'p' that are tangent to all three circles meet at a single point (i.e., they are concurrent), then prove that a certain real number 'n' equals 1.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes l m :: "'a::real_inner \<Rightarrow> 'a" and P1 P2 P3 :: "'a::real_inner" and n :: int
assumes h0 : "\<not> collinear {P1, P2, P3}"
and h1 : "\<not> (\<exists> m'. parallel l m' \<and> (m' P1 = m' P2 \<or> m' P2 = m' P3 \<or> m' P1 = m' P3))"
and h2 : "n = card {m. perpendicular l m \<and> (\<exists> Q. (\<forall> i \<in> {1,2,3}. tangent_circle_center Q (m i) (P i)))}"
shows  "n = 1"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three noncollinear points and a line $\ell$ are given in the plane. Suppose no two of the points lie on a line parallel to $\ell$ (or $\ell$ itself). There are exactly $n$ lines $m$ perpendicular to $\ell$ with the following property: the three circles with centers at the given points and tangent to line $m$ all concur at some point.  [asy] unitsize (1 cm); real func (real x) {   return(x^2/4); } real a, b, c; pair A, B, C, F; a = -2; b = 1.5; c = 3; A = (a,func(a)); B = (b,func(b)); C = (c,func(c)); F = (0,1); draw(graph(func,-4,5),red);

 draw(C--(c,-1),dashed); draw((-3,-2)--(-3,5.5)); label("$m$", (6,-1), E); label("$\ell$", (-3,5.5), N); dot(A); dot(B); dot(C); [/asy] Three noncollinear points in the coordinate plane determine a quadratic polynomial in $x$ unless two of the points have the same $x$-coordinate.
 Therefore, given the direction of the directrix, three noncollinear points determine a parabola, unless two of the points lie on a line perpendicular to the directrix. This case is ruled out by the given condition, so the answer is $\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes l m :: "'a::real_inner \<Rightarrow> 'a" and P1 P2 P3 :: "'a::real_inner" and n :: int
assumes h0 : "\<not> collinear {P1, P2, P3}"
and h1 : "\<not> (\<exists> m'. parallel l m' \<and> (m' P1 = m' P2 \<or> m' P2 = m' P3 \<or> m' P1 = m' P3))"
and h2 : "n = card {m. perpendicular l m \<and> (\<exists> Q. (\<forall> i \<in> {1,2,3}. tangent_circle_center Q (m i) (P i)))}"
shows  "n = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Consider three points P1, P2, and P3 in a plane which are not collinear. Now consider a line 'l' and a set of lines 'm'. There is no line 'm' parallel to 'l' such that it passes through any two of the points P1, P2, and P3. Let 'n' be the number of lines 'm' that are perpendicular to 'l' and for which there exists a point Q such that Q is the center of a circle tangent to line 'm' at points P1, P2, and P3. Find the value of 'n'. The final answer is 1.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n m l :: real and P1 P2 P3 :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "P1 ≠ P2 ∧ P2 ≠ P3 ∧ P1 ≠ P3"
and h1 : "¬(collinear P1 P2 P3)"
and h2 : "¬(exists l'. l' is_parallel l ∧ (P1 on l' ∨ P2 on l' ∨ P3 on l'))"
and h3 : "n = card {m. m is_perpendicular l ∧ 
  (exists P. P is_intersection 
    (circle_centered_at P1 tangent_to m) 
    (circle_centered_at P2 tangent_to m)
    (circle_centered_at P3 tangent_to m))}"
shows  "n = 1"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three noncollinear points and a line $\ell$ are given in the plane. Suppose no two of the points lie on a line parallel to $\ell$ (or $\ell$ itself). There are exactly $n$ lines $m$ perpendicular to $\ell$ with the following property: the three circles with centers at the given points and tangent to line $m$ all concur at some point. Find all possible values of $n$.

Enter all possible values of $n,$ separated by commas. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 The condition for line $m$ is that each of the three points lies at an equal distance from the line as from some fixed point; in other words, the line is the directrix of a parabola containing the three points, and the fixed point is the focus.
 [asy] unitsize (1 cm); real func (real x) {   return(x^2/4); } real a, b, c; pair A, B, C, F; a = -2; b = 1.5; c = 3; A = (a,func(a)); B = (b,func(b)); C = (c,func(c)); F = (0,1); draw(graph(func,-4,5),red);
 draw(Circle(A,abs(A - F))); draw(Circle(B,abs(B - F))); draw(Circle(C,abs(C - F))); draw((-4,-1)--(6,-1)); draw(A--F,dashed); draw(B--F,dashed); draw(C--F,dashed); draw(A--(a,-1),dashed); draw(B--(b,-1),dashed);
 draw(C--(c,-1),dashed); draw((-3,-2)--(-3,5.5)); label("$m$", (6,-1), E); label("$\ell$", (-3,5.5), N); dot(A); dot(B); dot(C); [/asy] Three noncollinear points in the coordinate plane determine a quadratic polynomial in $x$ unless two of the points have the same $x$-coordinate.
 Therefore, given the direction of the directrix, three noncollinear points determine a parabola, unless two of the points lie on a line perpendicular to the directrix. This case is ruled out by the given condition, so the answer is $\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n m l :: real and P1 P2 P3 :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "P1 ≠ P2 ∧ P2 ≠ P3 ∧ P1 ≠ P3"
and h1 : "¬(collinear P1 P2 P3)"
and h2 : "¬(exists l'. l' is_parallel l ∧ (P1 on l' ∨ P2 on l' ∨ P3 on l'))"
and h3 : "n = card {m. m is_perpendicular l ∧ 
  (exists P. P is_intersection 
    (circle_centered_at P1 tangent_to m) 
    (circle_centered_at P2 tangent_to m)
    (circle_centered_at P3 tangent_to m))}"
shows  "n = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given three distinct points P1, P2, and P3 that are not collinear and a line l, find the number of lines m that are perpendicular to line l and tangent to the circles centered at P1, P2, and P3, where these circles are tangent to line m. Furthermore, no line parallel to line l passes through any of P1, P2, or P3. The answer is that there exists exactly one such line m.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes l m :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and p1 p2 p3 :: complex
assumes h0 : "l \<noteq> m"
and h1 : "\<not> collinear p1 p2 p3"
and h2 : "\<not> (\<exists> l'. parallel l' l \<and> (l' passes_through p1 \<or> l' passes_through p2 \<or> l' passes_through p3))"
and h3 : "\<forall> m. perpendicular l m \<longrightarrow>
  (\<exists> p. concur_at p (circle p1 (distance p1 m)) (circle p2 (distance p2 m)) (circle p3 (distance p3 m)))"
shows  "card {m. perpendicular l m} = 1"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three noncollinear points and a line $\ell$ are given in the plane. Suppose no two of the points lie on a line parallel to $\ell$ (or $\ell$ itself). There are exactly $n$ lines $m$ perpendicular to $\ell$ with the following property: the three circles with centers at the given points and tangent to line $m$ all concur at some point. Find all possible values of $n$.

Enter all possible values of $n,$ separated by commas. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 The condition for line $m$ is that each of the three points lies at an equal distance from the line as from some fixed point; in other words, the line is the directrix of a parabola containing the three points, and the fixed point is the focus.
 [asy] unitsize (1 cm); real func (real x) {   return(x^2/4); } real a, b, c; pair A, B, C, F; a = -2; b = 1.5; c = 3; A = (a,func(a)); B = (b,func(b)); C = (c,func(c)); F = (0,1); draw(graph(func,-4,5),red);
 draw(Circle(A,abs(A - F))); draw(Circle(B,abs(B - F))); draw(Circle(C,abs(C - F))); draw((-4,-1)--(6,-1)); draw(A--F,dashed); draw(B--F,dashed); draw(C--F,dashed); draw(A--(a,-1),dashed); draw(B--(b,-1),dashed);
 draw(C--(c,-1),dashed); draw((-3,-2)--(-3,5.5)); label("$m$", (6,-1), E); label("$\ell$", (-3,5.5), N); dot(A); dot(B); dot(C); [/asy] Three noncollinear points in the coordinate plane determine a quadratic polynomial in $x$ unless two of the points have the same $x$-coordinate.
 Therefore, given the direction of the directrix, three noncollinear points determine a parabola, unless two of the points lie on a line perpendicular to the directrix. This case is ruled out by the given condition, so the answer is $\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes l m :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and p1 p2 p3 :: complex
assumes h0 : "l \<noteq> m"
and h1 : "\<not> collinear p1 p2 p3"
and h2 : "\<not> (\<exists> l'. parallel l' l \<and> (l' passes_through p1 \<or> l' passes_through p2 \<or> l' passes_through p3))"
and h3 : "\<forall> m. perpendicular l m \<longrightarrow>
  (\<exists> p. concur_at p (circle p1 (distance p1 m)) (circle p2 (distance p2 m)) (circle p3 (distance p3 m)))"
shows  "card {m. perpendicular l m} = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In a plane, given three non-collinear points p1, p2, and p3 and a line l, there is no other line parallel to l that passes through any of the points p1, p2, or p3. Furthermore, for any line m that is perpendicular to l, the three circles centered at p1, p2, and p3 with radii equal to their respective distances to m intersect at a common point. How many such lines m are there? The final answer is 1.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n m l :: real and points :: "(real, real) set"
assumes h0 : "points = {(x1, y1), (x2, y2), (x3, y3)}"
and h1 : "\<not> collinear points"
and h2 : "\<forall> p in points. \<not> parallel l (line_through p (other_point_on_line l p))"
and h3 : "n = card {m. perpendicular l m \<and> (\<exists> p. p = concur_point_of_circles_tangent_to_line_m m points)}"
shows  "n = 1"
a_6.formal solution:

 Therefore, given the direction of the directrix, three noncollinear points determine a parabola, unless two of the points lie on a line perpendicular to the directrix. This case is ruled out by the given condition, so the answer is $\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n m l :: real and points :: "(real, real) set"
assumes h0 : "points = {(x1, y1), (x2, y2), (x3, y3)}"
and h1 : "\<not> collinear points"
and h2 : "\<forall> p in points. \<not> parallel l (line_through p (other_point_on_line l p))"
and h3 : "n = card {m. perpendicular l m \<and> (\<exists> p. p = concur_point_of_circles_tangent_to_line_m m points)}"
shows  "n = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a set of three non-collinear points (x1, y1), (x2, y2), and (x3, y3), let's consider a line l such that none of the lines through the points and any other point on line l are parallel to l. Now let's consider all the lines m that are perpendicular to line l and for each such line m, there exists a point p which is the intersection point of three circles each tangent to line m and passing through one of the points from the set. How many such lines m exist? The answer is 1.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and l m :: "'a::euclidean_space \<Rightarrow> 'a::euclidean_space"
assumes h0 : "l \<noteq> m"
and h1 : "is_perpendicular l m"
and h2 : "\<forall> P Q R. \<not> collinear {P, Q, R} \<and> \<not> (P, Q, R) \<in> l \<and> \<not> (P, Q, R) \<in> m \<longrightarrow>
                    (\<exists> n. (\<forall> i \<le> n. tangent (circle P i) m) \<and>
                             (\<forall> i \<le> n. tangent (circle Q i) m) \<and>
                             (\<forall> i \<le> n. tangent (circle R i) m) \<and>
                             (\<forall> i > n. \<not> tangent (circle P i) m) \<and>
                             (\<forall> i > n. \<not> tangent (circle Q i) m) \<and>
                             (\<forall> i > n. \<not> tangent (circle R i) m))"
shows  "n = 1"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three noncollinear points and a line $\ell$ are given in the plane. Suppose no two of the points lie on a line parallel to $\ell$ (or $\ell$ itself). There are exactly $n$ lines $m$ perpendicular to $\ell$ with the following property: the three circles with centers at the given points and tangent to line $m$ all concur at some point. Find all possible values of $n$.

Enter all possible values of $n,$ separated by commas. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 The condition for line $m$ is that each of the three points lies at an equal distance from the line as from some fixed point; in other words, the line is the directrix of a parabola containing the three points, and the fixed point is the focus.
 [asy] unitsize (1 cm); real func (real x) {   return(x^2/4); } real a, b, c; pair A, B, C, F; a = -2; b = 1.5; c = 3; A = (a,func(a)); B = (b,func(b)); C = (c,func(c)); F = (0,1); draw(graph(func,-4,5),red);
 draw(Circle(A,abs(A - F))); draw(Circle(B,abs(B - F))); draw(Circle(C,abs(C - F))); draw((-4,-1)--(6,-1)); draw(A--F,dashed); draw(B--F,dashed); draw(C--F,dashed); draw(A--(a,-1),dashed); draw(B--(b,-1),dashed);
 draw(C--(c,-1),dashed); draw((-3,-2)--(-3,5.5)); label("$m$", (6,-1), E); label("$\ell$", (-3,5.5), N); dot(A); dot(B); dot(C); [/asy] Three noncollinear points in the coordinate plane determine a quadratic polynomial in $x$ unless two of the points have the same $x$-coordinate.
 Therefore, given the direction of the directrix, three noncollinear points determine a parabola, unless two of the points lie on a line perpendicular to the directrix. This case is ruled out by the given condition, so the answer is $\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and l m :: "'a::euclidean_space \<Rightarrow> 'a::euclidean_space"
assumes h0 : "l \<noteq> m"
and h1 : "is_perpendicular l m"
and h2 : "\<forall> P Q R. \<not> collinear {P, Q, R} \<and> \<not> (P, Q, R) \<in> l \<and> \<not> (P, Q, R) \<in> m \<longrightarrow>
                    (\<exists> n. (\<forall> i \<le> n. tangent (circle P i) m) \<and>
                             (\<forall> i \<le> n. tangent (circle Q i) m) \<and>
                             (\<forall> i \<le> n. tangent (circle R i) m) \<and>
                             (\<forall> i > n. \<not> tangent (circle P i) m) \<and>
                             (\<forall> i > n. \<not> tangent (circle Q i) m) \<and>
                             (\<forall> i > n. \<not> tangent (circle R i) m))"
shows  "n = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given two distinct perpendicular lines, l and m, and three non-collinear points P, Q, R that do not lie on these lines. There exists a natural number n such that the circles centered at P, Q, R with radius i (for all i ≤ n) are tangent to line m, and for all i > n, the circles are not tangent to line m. The question is to find this number n. The final answer is 1.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes l :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and m :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. l x \<noteq> m y"
and h1 : "noncollinear (l x) (l y) (l z)"
and h2 : "\<not> (\<exists> a. parallel a l \<and> (l x \<in> a \<or> l y \<in> a \<or> l z \<in> a))"
and h3 : "n = card {m. perpendicular m l \<and> (\<exists> p. concur (circle (l x) p m) (circle (l y) p m) (circle (l z) p m))}"
shows  "n = 1"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three noncollinear points and a line $\ell$ are given in the plane. Suppose no two of the points lie on a line parallel to $\ell$ (or $\ell$ itself). There are exactly $n$ lines $m$ perpendicular to $\ell$ with the following property: the three circles with centers at the given points and tangent to line $m$ all concur at some point. Find all possible values of $n$.

Enter all possible values of $n,$ separated by commas. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 The condition for line $m$ is that each of the three points lies at an equal distance from the line as from some fixed point; in other words, the line is the directrix of a parabola containing the three points, and the fixed point is the focus.
 [asy] unitsize (1 cm); real func (real x) {   return(x^2/4); } real a, b, c; pair A, B, C, F; a = -2; b = 1.5; c = 3; A = (a,func(a)); B = (b,func(b)); C = (c,func(c)); F = (0,1); draw(graph(func,-4,5),red);
 draw(Circle(A,abs(A - F))); draw(Circle(B,abs(B - F))); draw(Circle(C,abs(C - F))); draw((-4,-1)--(6,-1)); draw(A--F,dashed); draw(B--F,dashed); draw(C--F,dashed); draw(A--(a,-1),dashed); draw(B--(b,-1),dashed);
 draw(C--(c,-1),dashed); draw((-3,-2)--(-3,5.5)); label("$m$", (6,-1), E); label("$\ell$", (-3,5.5), N); dot(A); dot(B); dot(C); [/asy] Three noncollinear points in the coordinate plane determine a quadratic polynomial in $x$ unless two of the points have the same $x$-coordinate.
 Therefore, given the direction of the directrix, three noncollinear points determine a parabola, unless two of the points lie on a line perpendicular to the directrix. This case is ruled out by the given condition, so the answer is $\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes l :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and m :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. l x \<noteq> m y"
and h1 : "noncollinear (l x) (l y) (l z)"
and h2 : "\<not> (\<exists> a. parallel a l \<and> (l x \<in> a \<or> l y \<in> a \<or> l z \<in> a))"
and h3 : "n = card {m. perpendicular m l \<and> (\<exists> p. concur (circle (l x) p m) (circle (l y) p m) (circle (l z) p m))}"
shows  "n = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Consider three non-collinear points l(x), l(y), and l(z) such that there is no line 'a' parallel to a line 'l' passing through any of these points. Let 'n' represent the number of lines 'm' that are perpendicular to 'l' and concurrent with three circles, each centered at one of the points and passing through a common point 'p'. Determine the value of 'n'. The final answer is 'n' equals 1.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes l m :: "'a::real_normed_vector \<Rightarrow> 'a::real_normed_vector"
and p1 p2 p3 :: "'a::real_normed_vector"
and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "¬ colinear {p1, p2, p3}"
and h1 : "¬ ((p1 - p2) \<parallel> l)"
and h2 : "¬ ((p1 - p3) \<parallel> l)"
and h3 : "¬ ((p2 - p3) \<parallel> l)"
and h4 : "\<forall> m. orthogonal l m \<longrightarrow> 
           (\<exists> p. concur p (circle p1 p) (circle p2 p) (circle p3 p)) \<longrightarrow> n = card {m}"
shows  "n = 1"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three noncollinear points and a line $\ell$ are given in the plane. Suppose no two of the points lie on a line parallel to $\ell$ (or $\ell$ itself). There are exactly $n$ lines $m$ perpendicular to $\ell$ with the following property: the three circles with centers at the given points and tangent to line $m$ all concur at some point. Find all possible values of $n$.

Enter all possible values of $n,$ separated by commas. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 The condition for line $m$ is that each of the three points lies at an equal distance from the line as from some fixed point; in other words, the line is the directrix of a parabola containing the three points, and the fixed point is the focus.
 [asy] unitsize (1 cm); real func (real x) {   return(x^2/4); } real a, b, c; pair A, B, C, F; a = -2; b = 1.5; c = 3; A = (a,func(a)); B = (b,func(b)); C = (c,func(c)); F = (0,1); draw(graph(func,-4,5),red);
 draw(Circle(A,abs(A - F))); draw(Circle(B,abs(B - F))); draw(Circle(C,abs(C - F))); draw((-4,-1)--(6,-1)); draw(A--F,dashed); draw(B--F,dashed); draw(C--F,dashed); draw(A--(a,-1),dashed); draw(B--(b,-1),dashed);
 draw(C--(c,-1),dashed); draw((-3,-2)--(-3,5.5)); label("$m$", (6,-1), E); label("$\ell$", (-3,5.5), N); dot(A); dot(B); dot(C); [/asy] Three noncollinear points in the coordinate plane determine a quadratic polynomial in $x$ unless two of the points have the same $x$-coordinate.
 Therefore, given the direction of the directrix, three noncollinear points determine a parabola, unless two of the points lie on a line perpendicular to the directrix. This case is ruled out by the given condition, so the answer is $\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes l m :: "'a::real_normed_vector \<Rightarrow> 'a::real_normed_vector"
and p1 p2 p3 :: "'a::real_normed_vector"
and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "¬ colinear {p1, p2, p3}"
and h1 : "¬ ((p1 - p2) \<parallel> l)"
and h2 : "¬ ((p1 - p3) \<parallel> l)"
and h3 : "¬ ((p2 - p3) \<parallel> l)"
and h4 : "\<forall> m. orthogonal l m \<longrightarrow> 
           (\<exists> p. concur p (circle p1 p) (circle p2 p) (circle p3 p)) \<longrightarrow> n = card {m}"
shows  "n = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given three points p1, p2, and p3 in a real normed vector space that are not colinear. If none of the vectors formed by subtracting any two points is parallel to a given vector l, then there exists a unique vector m orthogonal to l such that the circles centered at points p1, p2, and p3 concur at some point p. Find the cardinality of the set containing all such vectors m. The final answer is 1.
